ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I built on my knowledge from the first Organic Lab sequence, both in general techniques but also being able to make decisions in what to do next.
A lot of wet lab skills

SO MUCH LAB STUFF! I learned techniques I never could have imagined covering in an undergraduate class. Extraction, GC-MS, purification with the Biotage, use of microwave reactor instead of reflux, 2D NMR, and even more synthesis techniques. I also learned that maybe organic synthesis is not for me haha but we did so much that I'm more confident saying that. I also grew as a writer and a scientist.
How to perform independent research and write scientific papers.
I learned about a lot of new chemistry lab techniques that I had never heard of in previous lab classes, and also learned how to be confident in a lab without being told what to do or think.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a bit disorganized in terms of Canvas and knowing when assignments and such were due

The main weakness of this course is also its strength. This course teaches you how to manage your own time and be independent in a research setting. However, this loose structure also means that deadlines can be very unclear, which leads to feeling behind and overwhelmed by assignments all of a sudden. I think with more clear deadlines, this class could keep the independent aspect and still maintain the sanity of its students.

This class was the best chemistry course I have taken at Yale, in that it taught independence and critical thinking in a lab, and also was an extremely friendly, encouraging environment. The only thing I would change is the speed of the course: maybe get into and start the first experiment earlier so there was more time at the end to do final projects.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! It is a great stepping stone to research settings!
I would, but it is a large time commitment just due to the hours in class

Only take this class if you're really prepared to commit to the workload. Some weeks it'll be really light, and others you'll have a final paper and proposal due within two days of each other. It's a rewarding course to take though! It definitely prepared more for a career as a researcher.
Yes, I definitely would!! It is a great way to be introduced to the field of scientific research.

100%. It is everything a person could want in a class. Dr. DiMeglio and Taylor were so knowledgeable and great teachers, I felt like I was accomplishing and learning things throughout the class but was not stressed about it, and it reminded me that chemistry can be enjoyable.
